title: Protocol to generate endothelial cells, pericytes, and fibroblasts in one differentiation round from human-induced pluripotent stem cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Induced pluripotent stem Cell (iPSC) plating for APEL2 differentiation
Timing: 7 days
This step explains how to begin the differentiation. Undifferentiated iPSC can be plated and next day the differentiation begins. 7 days of differentiation is composed with simple medium changes every 2 days. There are 2 different media: day 1–3 and day 3–7.
Prepare coating of 6 well plates by adding of 1 mL of vitronectin solution to each well of entire surface and leave at 17°C–22°C for 1 h.
Note: Do not leave in the biosafety laminar flow hood since it can cause drying of the plates. Leave on tabletop if not disturbed. If the plate is not used, store at 4°C refrigerator. Wrap with clean aluminum foil in case needed to avoid contamination.
Bring E8 medium and versene to 17°C–22°C by leaving on the tabletop for 15 min.
Critical: Do not warm up the E8 medium at 37°C since bFGF half-life in E8 medium is temperature sensitive.
Grow iPSC in iPSC culture media (E8 medium) in a 6-well plate. When iPSC culture reaches to 80% confluency cells can be prepared to initiate differentiation.
Wash cells once in 2 mL PBS/well.
Add 1 mL versene/well and incubate for 5 min at 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator.
Swirl or gently tap the side of plate to detach cells.
Note: If the cells don’t lift, do not pipet to detach. Leave another 5 min at 17°C–22°C and swirl or gently tap the side of the plate.
Transfer 80 μL of cells along with versene solution to each well of a new 6-well plate precoated with vitronectin and containing 2 mL of E8 medium including 5 μM of Rock inhibitor.
Prepare 2-3 plates (12–18 wells) for the differentiation set.

Next day, begin the APEL2 (Albumin Poly-vinyl-alcohol Essential Lipids) differentiation process with iPSC cultures that have small colonies and a density of 10%–20% (See Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1], Day 2)
Remove E8 medium from iPSC and add 2.5 mL of day 1–3 differentiation medium for days 1–3. Mark the starting day as day 1.
Keep the plate in a 37°C incubator until day 3 without changing medium for 48 h.
On day 3, prepare day 3–7 medium and warm up to 17°C–22°C.
Remove plate from the 37°C incubator. Swirl it before removing the medium in order to remove most of the floating cells. It is expected to observe significant numbers of floating cells.
Replace with 2.5 mL of day 3–7 medium at day 3.
Replace with 3 mL of day 3–7 medium at day 5.
MACS sorting and plating the CD31+ and CD31− cells
Timing: 3–4 h
This step explains single cell preparation of differentiating cells, antibody staining for magnetic cell sorting separation, and culture of purified CD31− and CD31+ cells.
Cell preparation for MACS
At day 7 of APEL differentiation, wash cells once with 2 mL PBS per well.
Add 1 mL of TrypLE.
Incubate 5 min at 37°C incubator.
Use P1000 pipet to gently detach cells and incubate another 5 min.
Collect cells in 50 mL conical tube that already include 10 mL MACS buffer to stop TrypLE.
Use MACS buffer to wash wells and add to cell suspension.
Make total volume 45 mL with MACS buffer that includes cells from 12–18 wells.
Note: dilute the cell suspension enough to see through the solution. If the cell solution is too dense, loss of cells at the filtering step will be greater.
Filter cell solution through 20 μm cell strainer.
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Antibody staining

Remove the supernatant and tap the tube to dislodge the cell pellet.
Add 5 mL MACS buffer including 5 μM Rock inhibitor final concentration per 6 wells (one 6-well plate) equivalent cells for cell count.
Note: Expect to yield around 1.5 ± 0.16 × 106 cells (N = 12 experiments) from one well of 6-well plate at this stage.
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100g.
Remove the supernatant and tap the tube to dislodge the cell pellet.
Add MACS buffer including 5 μM Rock inhibitor and FcR blocker (from CD31 microbead kit) and mix well with the cells (See the Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] for volume)
Add anti-CD31 microbead to the cell solution and pipet to mix or gently vortex the solution.
Note: See Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] for appropriate volume for staining.
Incubate microbead-cell solution for 15 min at 4°C.
Add 20 mL of MACS buffer for approximately 1 × 107 cells equivalent for washing.
filter through 20 μm cell strainer.
Note: Magnetic beads tagged microbeads form less than 1 μm in diameter on cell surfaces, even with massive labeling, so they will not interfere with filtration through the 20 μm cell strainer.
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Cell separation
During the centrifugation, set the magnetic station, LS separation column, and 15 mL conical tubes below the column.
Add 2 mL of MACS buffer to wash the column.
Once centrifugation is complete, remove the supernatant and tap the tube to dislodge the pellet.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL of MACS buffer including 5 μM Rock inhibitor for less than 2 × 109 cells (Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]).
Load cells on the top of the LS column.
Collect the CD31− flow through of cells.

Add 3 mL of MACS buffer to the column and collect the 1st wash of cell flow through that will lead to total 6 mL of cell solution (see steps 3b. and 3d.).
Change to new conical tube and wash 2 more times with 3 mL of MACS buffer. Discard these two wash throughs.
Detach the column from the magnetic station and put above a new conical tube labeled CD31+ cells.
Add 2 mL of EGM2 medium or MACS buffer including 5 μM Rock inhibitor to the top of LS column.
Immediately flush out the medium to collect CD31+ cells.
Cell plating
Centrifuge CD31− cells and resuspend in 1 mL of EGM2 medium per column eluted including 5 μM Rock inhibitor.
e.g., Resuspend in 4 mL if eluted from 4 LS columns.
Take 10 μL of cell solution and mix with 10 μL of trypan blue to count live cell number.
Note: Expected to yield 8.3 ± 0.65 × 105 cells (69 ± 1.2% of pre-sort population, N = 5 experiments).
Count CD31+ cells with the same method. Additional centrifugation is not necessary if the cells were eluted in CD31+ EGM2 plating medium.
Note: Expected to yield 2.7 ± 0.02 × 105 cells (17.4 ± 1.3% of pre-sort population, N = 7 experiments).
Plate 1 × 104 CD31+ cells/cm2 on fibronectin coated flasks in CD31+ EGM2 plating medium (7.5 × 105 cells/T75 flask).
Plate 2 × 104 CD31− cells/ cm2 on gelatin coated flasks in CD31− EGM2 plating medium (maximum plating density 1.5 × 106 cells/T75 flask).
Induced endothelial cell (iEC) expansion, freezing and thawing
Timing: 1–2 weeks
This step explains how to expand iEC prior to cryopreservation, thaw and recover from thawing before used for experiments.
Change the medium

Next day of MACS, change medium of CD31+ cells with iEC complete medium including VEGF (25 ng/mL), bFGF (20 ng/mL), and CTGF (10 ng/mL).3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Change medium every 2 or 3 days.
Cells will be 80%–90% confluent about 5–7 days after plating from MACS (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2680-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Phase contrast images of MACS isolated CD31+ endothelial cells
CD31+ cells were plated onto the fibronectin coated culture plate and expanded for 5–7 days considered as passage 0 (P0). Cells were cryopreserved until the experiment. When thawed (P1) and passaged, cells demonstrated typical endothelial cell morphology. It is not recommended to passage cells beyond P3. Scale bars are 250 μm.
Avoid culturing more than 7 days. Cells will accumulate extracellular matrix (ECM) and will be difficult to detach from the flask.
Expansion of iEC.
When CD31+ iEC reach near 80%–90% confluency, cells are washed in 10 mL PBS.
Remove PBS and add 5 mL of TrypLE. Incubate 5 min at 37°C.
Tap the side of flasks to detach cells. Observe under the microscope and incubate another 5 min if some cells are still attached.
Collect all the cells in 5 mL iEC complete medium to stop TrypLE per 75T flasks.
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend in 1 mL iEC medium per 75T flask harvested.
Count the cell number.
Plate to new pre-coated flasks with fibronectin solution with density of 5 × 105 cells/75T-flask or cryopreserve.
Cryopreservation of iEC
When CD31+ iEC reach near 80%–90% confluency, cells are washed in 10 mL PBS.
Remove PBS and add 5 mL of TrypLE. Incubate 5 min at 37°C.
Tap the side of flasks to detach cells. Observe under the microscope and incubate another 5 min if some cells are still attached.
Resuspend in 1 mL iEC medium per 75T flask harvested.

Count the cell number.
Note: Expect to harvest around 2 fold increase from the initial seeding density. E.g., 1.5 ± 0.17 × 106 cells from one 75T (P1, N = 6 experiments) after 7 days of expansion that were seeded with 7.5 × 105 cells/75T flask
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Tap to dislodge the pellet and resuspend in CryoStor with the density of 1 million/mL. Label as passage number 0 (P0).
Distribute cell solution into cryovials, recommended at 1 mL/vial.
Freeze in Mr. Frosty with isopropanol or equivalent freezing container at −80°C.
Next day move into liquid nitrogen tank.
Pause point: Cells are frozen and can be paused at this step.
Thawing iEC
Thaw cells in 37°C water bath for 2 min.
Move cell solution into a conical tube with 10 mL of iEC complete medium added slowly and with frequent agitation.
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend in iEC complete medium containing 5 μM rock inhibitor.
Plate 1 million cells (1 vial) into 2 of T75 flasks precoated with human fibronectin.
Change to iEC complete medium next day and every 2 or 3 days thereafter.
Cells will be 80%–90% confluent in 5–7 days.
Pre-induced pericytes (Pre-iPC) to induced pericyte (iPC) differentiation, cryopreservation, and thawing
Timing: 2–5 weeks
This step explains how to differentiate pre-iPC (P0 in EGM2, P1 in Pericyte differentiation medium) to iPC (P2-P5 in Pericyte expansion medium). Seeding density in each passage is important to follow.
Pre-iPC to iPC differentiation
Timing: 1–2 weeks
Change the medium.
The day after plating CD31− cells from MACS, change EGM2 complete medium and then every 2–3 days.
Cells will be confluent in 4–5 days.
Wash in 10 mL PBS and add 5 mL of TrypLE.
Incubate for 5 min at 37°C.

Tab the side of flasks to detach cells.
Collect cells in 10 mL Pericyte differentiation medium and centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend cells in Pericyte differentiation medium (see the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) with 5 μM Rock inhibitor.
Count cells and plate 1–2 million cells/T75-flask or 1:1 ratio. Mark as P1.
Note: Expect to harvest 1–2 million cells from P0. It can be passaged to 1:1 ratio to P1 in Pericyte differentiation medium (e.g., 1 flask to 1 flask). It is recommended to have high number of cells to be carried to the next passage.
Next day, change to 15 mL of Pericyte differentiation medium without Rock inhibitor per 75T flask.
Change medium every 2–3 days.
Note: Cell morphology will change, and cells will increase in size with high cytoskeleton accumulation (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2680-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Phase contrast images of CD31− MACS isolated and matured iPSC-derived pericyte (iPericytes)
CD31− cells were plated onto the gelatin coated cell culture plate with high cell density. Cells were passaged 3–4 days after into pericyte differentiation medium including DMEM, 10% FBS, PDGF-bb, and TGFβ3. After the first passage (P1), pericytes were grown in Pericyte expansion medium up to passage 4–5. It is not recommended to use cells beyond passage 5. Scale bars are 250 μm.
iPC expansion, cryopreservation, and thawing
Timing: 7 days each passage
Change the medium.
Pre-pericyte (P1) will be confluent in 5–7 days.
Wash in 10 mL PBS and add 5 mL of TrypLE.
Incubate for 5 min at 37°C.
Tab the side of flasks to detach cells.
Collect cells in 10 mL Pericyte expansion medium and centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend cells in Pericyte expansion medium (see the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) with 5 μM Rock inhibitor.
Count cells and plate 0.75–1 × 106 cells/T75-flask

Next day, change medium to Pericyte expansion medium without Rock inhibitor.
Change medium every 2 or 3 days.
Passage of iPC.
After 7 days of culture from previous passage (P2) or when cells reach 80–90% confluency, wash once in 10 mL PBS and add 5 mL of TrypLE.
Incubate 5 min at 37°C.
Tab the side of flasks to detach cells.
Collect cells in Pericyte expansion medium and centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend in 1 mL of Pericyte expansion medium per 75T flask harvested.
Count the cell number.
Plate to new pre-coated flasks with gelatin solution with density of 5 × 105 cells/75T-flask or cryopreserve.
Expand up to passage 4–5.
Note: Pericytes demonstrated bigger cell body and low proliferation rate compared to fibroblasts. It was often observed that pericytes showed lower than 2-fold expansion rate after 7 days of expansion.
Cryopreservation of iPC.
When cells are 80%–90% confluent, wash once in 10 mL PBS and add 5 mL of TrypLE.
Incubate 5 min at 37°C.
Tab the side of flasks to detach cells.
Collect cells in Pericyte expansion medium and centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend in 1 mL of Pericyte expansion medium per 75T flask harvested.
Count the cell number.
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Tap to dislodge the pellet and resuspend in CryoStor with the density of 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Distribute cell solution into cryovials, at 1 mL/vial.
Freeze in Mr. Frosty with isopropanol or equivalent freezing container at −80°C.
Next day move the vials into a liquid nitrogen tank.
Pause point: Cells are frozen and can be paused at this step.
Thawing of iPCs.
Coat T75 flasks with 0.1% gelatin solution.
Bring frozen vial(s) to 37°C warm water bath.
Rapidly thaw cells within 2 min.

Move 1 mL of cell solution into conical tubes with 9 mL of Pericyte expansion medium (total 10 mL).
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend in 10 mL of Pericyte expansion medium including 5 μM Rock inhibitor.
Plate 1 vial to 1 of T75 flask (1 × 106 cells/flask).
Note: iPC requires higher seeding density as compared to iEC and iFibroblasts and will demonstrate slower proliferation rate.
iPC to induced-fibroblasts (iFibroblasts) differentiation, cryopreservation, and thawing
Timing: 2–5 weeks
This step explains how to differentiate iPC (P2-P5 in Pericyte expansion medium) to iFibroblast (P2-P8 FibroLife medium).
iPC to iFibroblasts differentiation
Timing: 1–2 weeks
Change medium to differentiate iPC to iFibroblasts.
Between passage 2–5 and when iPC are 70% confluent, change medium to FibroLife instead of Pericyte expansion medium for pre-conditioning.
Two days later wash iPC in 10 mL PBS and add 5 mL of TrypLE.
Incubate 5 min at 37°C.
Tab the side of flasks to detach cells.
Collect cells in FibroLife medium and centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Count the cell number.
Plate iPC into a new T75 flask with density of 1 × 106 cells/ 75T-flask in 12 mL of FibroLife medium including 5 μM Rock inhibitor. Mark as P1.
Change medium the next day to FibroLife without Rock inhibitor and every 2 or 3 days thereafter.
Repeat one more passage with density of 5 × 105 cells/75T flask in 12 mL of FibroLife. medium including 5 μM Rock inhibitor. Mark as P2.
Note: iFibroblasts will demonstrate reduced cell size, elongated cell shape, and higher proliferation rate. It is expected to harvest 3–4 fold expansion.
iFibroblasts expansion, cryopreservation, and thawing
Timing: 7 days each passage
Expansion of iFibroblsts.
When P2 cells are 80%–90% confluent wash once in 10 mL PBS and add 5 mL of TrypLE.

Tab the side of flasks to detach cells.
Collect cells in FibroLife medium and centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend in 1 mL of FibroLife medium per 75T flask harvested.
Count the cell number.
Plate iPC into a new uncoated T75 flask with density of 5 × 105 cells/ 75T-flask in 12 mL of FibroLife medium including 5 μM Rock inhibitor. Mark as P3.
Note: do not expand beyond passage 7 or 8 in FibroLife and cryopreserve at early passage (e.g., P2-3 in FibroLife).
Cryopreservation of iFibroblasts.
Cryopreserve iFibroblasts after 2–3 passages in Fibroblast fate to ensure this fate is stabilized in cells (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2680-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Phase contrast images of iPSC-derived fibroblasts (iFibroblast)
Pericytes are differentiated into fibroblasts using FibroLife medium on un-coated 75T-flasks. Cells demonstrated high proliferative rate up to passage 7–8. When cells demonstrate bigger cell size and slow proliferation (P9), it is recommended to discard and use earlier passage. Scale bars are 250 μm.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2680-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Flow cytometry analysis of day 7 APEL differentiated cells
(A and B) (A) Comparisons of APEL2-Li and APEL2 on day 7 differentiating cells, and (B) Post-sort analysis of endothelial (CD31, CD146, CD144) and mesenchymal pericyte (CD146, CD140b, CD73) protein expression. Note: APEL2-Li and APEL2 media behave similar for this differentiation. Either of the two media can be used.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2680-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. iPSC derived-endothelial cell (iEC) characterization
(A) iEC express common endothelial cell protein such as CD31, ETV2 and von Willebrand Factor (vWF). Scale bars are 50 μm.
(B) Majority of iECs uptake acetylated low density lipoprotein (Ac-LDL) that are visualized by Dil fluorescent tagged Ac-LDL shown in microscopy and analyzed by flow cytometry. Scale bars are 250 μm.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2680-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. iPSC derived-pericyte (iPC) characterization

(A–C) iPCs demonstrate (A) large high cell body size with highly developed cytoskeletons, clear cell membrane and extensions of cell bodies, express known pericyte markers such as (B) CD140b (a.k.a. PDGFR-b) (C) NG2, collagen type I (Col-I). Portions of iPC include alpha smooth muscle actin (aSMA) expressing cells. Scale bars are (A) 250 μm and (C) 50 μm.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2680-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. iPSC-derived fibroblasts (iFibroblasts) characterization
iFibroblasts express collagen type-I (Collagen-I), vimentin, connexin43 but not NG2, PDGFRb, and alpha-smooth muscle actin (aSMA). Scale bars are 100 μm for Collagen-I, 250 μm for phase contrast, and 50 μm for all other images.
Resuspend iFibroblasts 1 × 106 cells/mL of CryoStore CS10.
Distribute 1 mL each cryovial.
Freeze cryovials in Mr. Frosty with isopropanol or equivalent freezing container at −80°C.
Next day move frozen vials into liquid nitrogen tank.
Pause point: Cells are frozen and can be paused at this step.
Thawing of iFibroblasts.
Bring a frozen vial to 37°C warm water bath.
Rapidly thaw cells within 2 min.
Move cells into conical tubes by slowly adding 9 mL of FibroLife medium with frequent agitation (total volume 10 mL).
Centrifuge for 5 min, 100 g.
Resuspend in 10 mL of FibroLife medium including 5 μM Rock inhibitor to ensure cell viability of cells post thaw.
Plate 1 vial to 2 of T75 flasks.
Next day, replace medium with 12 mL of FibroLife medium without Rock inhibitor.
